alert.note: Alert for Calabasas and Agoura Hills; Central Ventura County Valleys; Eastern San Gabriel Mountains; Interstate 5 Corridor; Santa Clarita Valley; Santa Susana Mountains; Southeastern Ventura County Valleys; Southern Ventura County Mountains; Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor; Western Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued October 30 at 1:53PM PDT until October 31 at 2:00PM PDT by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...RED FLAG WARNING EXTENDED THROUGH 2 PM TUESDAY FOR WIND PRONE MOUNTAINS AND VALLEYS OF LOS ANGELES AND VENTURA COUNTY... ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT THROUGH 10 PM FOR LESS WIND PRONE COASTS, MOST VALLEYS OF LA COUNTY, AND THE EASTERN SANTA MONICA MOUNTAINS... .Moderate Santa Ana winds and very dry conditions are expected to continue through early Tuesday afternoon and has prompted the extension of the Red Flag Warning through 2 pm Tuesday for the most wind prone mountains and valleys of Los Angeles and Ventura Counties. Wind gusts of 30 to 50 mph will be common during this time with humidity values generally in the 5 to 15 percent range, even overnight for wind prone areas. ...RED FLAG WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM PDT TUESDAY FOR GUSTY SANTA ANA WINDS AND VERY LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR VALLEYS OF LOS ANGELES AND VENTURA COUNTIES AS WELL AS THE VENTURA COUNTY MOUNTAINS AND EASTERN SANTA MONICAS... * Winds...Northeast to east 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 50 mph. * Relative Humidity...Minimum humidity of 5 to 10 percent. Very poor humidity recoveries of 10 to 20 percent in wind prone areas. * Impacts...If fire ignition occurs there could be rapid spread of wildfire that would lead to a threat to life and property.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now, or will shortly. Use extreme caution with anything that can spark a wildfire. Residents near wildland interfaces should be prepared to evacuate if a wildfire breaks out. See readyforwildfire.org and wildfirerisk.org for information.
